Summary: The proposal aims to develop a neurobiologically grounded attention model integrating top-down and bottom-up mechanisms, validated using neural data (EEG/fMRI) and behavioral tasks. It features a three-part approach: model architecture, neural data integration, and behavioral validation, with a detailed step-by-step experiment plan.
Strengths: Intellectually ambitious hypothesis grounded in cognitive neuroscience literature.
Comprehensive three-part approach and detailed experiment plan.
Strong alignment with cognitive neuroscience principles.
Weaknesses: Lacks detailed discussion on technical challenges (e.g., multi-modal neural data integration).
Execution feasibility of real-time dynamic gating mechanisms is not thoroughly addressed.
Validation plan could be more explicit on performance quantification against baselines.
No discussion on potential ethical concerns related to human neural data use.
Questions: What specific technical challenges do you anticipate in integrating EEG and fMRI data, and how will you address them?
How will the real-time dynamic gating mechanisms be computationally implemented and validated?
What metrics will be used to quantify the model's performance against baseline models?
What specific datasets will be used for training and validation?
Limitations: Potential computational complexity of the proposed dynamic gating mechanisms.
Challenges in aligning model activations with multi-modal neural data.
Generalizability of the model to diverse attention tasks and individual differences.
